snippet.textDisplay: Have you gotten around to replay CC? It's my one of my favorites.

snippet.textDisplay: On more than one occasion, I've heard the VGM well before playing the game, then when I actually hear the music while playing the game, it's that much more special of an experience because it's finally in context.  Specifically I'm thinking of Knuckles Chaotix, and a few other Sonic Team games.
snippet.textOriginal: On more than one occasion, I've heard the VGM well before playing the game, then when I actually hear the music while playing the game, it's that much more special of an experience because it's finally in context.  Specifically I'm thinking of Knuckles Chaotix, and a few other Sonic Team games.

snippet.textDisplay: Often times I found that if I listen to a song a lot, when I hear it in context in the game it just strikes me much more emotional then if I was hearing it for the first time...
snippet.textOriginal: Often times I found that if I listen to a song a lot, when I hear it in context in the game it just strikes me much more emotional then if I was hearing it for the first time...

snippet.textDisplay: I personally feel that there are certain songs that sound five times better when you hear them in their proper execution. It's hard to explain but sometimes storyline-based games can give you the proper mindset to make specific songs have more power to them rather than just listening to them like this.
snippet.textOriginal: I personally feel that there are certain songs that sound five times better when you hear them in their proper execution. It's hard to explain but sometimes storyline-based games can give you the proper mindset to make specific songs have more power to them rather than just listening to them like this.

snippet.textDisplay:
Favorite character time: 

I'd have to say I'm torn between Harle and Kid. In some of the CG's though, Harle looks absolutely gorgeous.... Almost makes me wonder what she truly looked like without her costume and all that makeup.

snippet.textDisplay: @SupraDarky I understand where dx619hey is coming from by saying that hearing vg music before experiencing it in game can spoil the experience.  In times before youtube this wasn't an issue.  But really, if you're interested in a game's music, you owe it to yourself to play through it before coming on here.  Then after that you can listen to the music and think back on it.
snippet.textOriginal: @SupraDarky I understand where dx619hey is coming from by saying that hearing vg music before experiencing it in game can spoil the experience.  In times before youtube this wasn't an issue.  But really, if you're interested in a game's music, you owe it to yourself to play through it before coming on here.  Then after that you can listen to the music and think back on it.

snippet.textDisplay:
So much tension and sadness in this piece. You really do feel like floating slowly in still water as broken pieces of boats and bones of victims float about around you. Each one gently whispering to you their last memories...

Mitsuda is amazing at painting these pictures.
snippet.textOriginal:
So much tension and sadness in this piece. You really do feel like floating slowly in still water as broken pieces of boats and bones of victims float about around you. Each one gently whispering to you their last memories...

Mitsuda is amazing at painting these pictures.

snippet.textDisplay: @dx619hey Late answer, but there's really nothing I can do about that. The best thing I'd say about that is not to click on the video in the first place if you're afraid of being spoiled in any way, including hearing a VGM.
snippet.textOriginal: @dx619hey Late answer, but there's really nothing I can do about that. The best thing I'd say about that is not to click on the video in the first place if you're afraid of being spoiled in any way, including hearing a VGM.

snippet.textDisplay: This game had an amazing soundtrack (Mitsuda was on top of his game during the PS1 years) but the game itself just didn't deliver the same kind of spirited and swashbuckling fun as the first game.

snippet.textDisplay: This song, along with the setting it played in, were absolutely sublime. The atmosphere was very memorable, and had an eerie sense of beauty and longing. This and Dragon's Prayer are probably my faves of the soundtrack.

snippet.textDisplay: Chrono Cross' soundtrack is filled with so many emotionally charged pieces. The battle with Miguel at the Dead Sea, with its theme, makes this level quite possibly the most memorable in the game. It's a toss-up between the Dead Sea and Fort Dragonia, IMO.
snippet.textOriginal: Chrono Cross' soundtrack is filled with so many emotionally charged pieces. The battle with Miguel at the Dead Sea, with its theme, makes this level quite possibly the most memorable in the game. It's a toss-up between the Dead Sea and Fort Dragonia, IMO.

snippet.textDisplay:
Stats update: Chrono Cross has reached the 7-song mark... quite a feat on this list, putting it almost halfway towards its predecessor Chrono Trigger's 15 songs.  
Chrono Cross is the only the second game published after 1999 to reach 7 songs.
snippet.textOriginal:
Stats update: Chrono Cross has reached the 7-song mark... quite a feat on this list, putting it almost halfway towards its predecessor Chrono Trigger's 15 songs.  
Chrono Cross is the only the second game published after 1999 to reach 7 songs.

snippet.textDisplay: I do have to say that this game some crazy twists that were just NUTS!  But I still liked it...  Also, this song kinda reminds me of the theme from Parasite Eve.

snippet.textDisplay: I was also just thinking how I needed to play this game again.  Played it about a year and a half ago, but since this is my favorite game of all time, I think another playthrough might be in order!  Especially so I can hear amazing songs like Dead Sea, which is one of the best songs in the game.

snippet.textDisplay:
@SupraDarky Do you ever worry about "spoiling the experience" for gamers that haven't played a VGM's game? Like this memorable part of the game may not be so memorable for people, when they play it after listening to it's music through you. I'm not accusing you of it, I'm just wondering your take on this. 

Or, have you ever felt that listening to a VGM before hearing it in the game's context has spoiled that part of the game?
snippet.textOriginal:
@SupraDarky Do you ever worry about "spoiling the experience" for gamers that haven't played a VGM's game? Like this memorable part of the game may not be so memorable for people, when they play it after listening to it's music through you. I'm not accusing you of it, I'm just wondering your take on this. 

Or, have you ever felt that listening to a VGM before hearing it in the game's context has spoiled that part of the game?

snippet.textDisplay: I love how it's a remix of Sealed Door from Chrono Trigger by Mitsuda. A piece originally done by Uematsu when he completed the last few tracks of the CT OST when Mitsuda got sick.
snippet.textOriginal: I love how it's a remix of Sealed Door from Chrono Trigger by Mitsuda. A piece originally done by Uematsu when he completed the last few tracks of the CT OST when Mitsuda got sick.

snippet.textDisplay: While I almost play Chrono Trigger yearly, I haven't played Chrono Cross in a long while. Time is my biggest enemy right now, but I'll get to a replay of this game when I can. I remember the Dead Sea very well though, it was pretty memorable, especially with Nadia's Bell at the center.
snippet.textOriginal: While I almost play Chrono Trigger yearly, I haven't played Chrono Cross in a long while. Time is my biggest enemy right now, but I'll get to a replay of this game when I can. I remember the Dead Sea very well though, it was pretty memorable, especially with Nadia's Bell at the center.
